title: Ticket #899: ALLOW_CONFIG=* as used by condor_config_val -rset is broken
description:
config:
ENABLE_RUNTIME_CONFIG = TRUE
ALLOW_CONFIG = *
SETTABLE_ATTRS_CONFIG = *

test:
$ condor_config_val -neg -rset A=1
Attempt to set configuration "A=1" on negotiator robin.local <127.0.0.1:44380> failed.

NegotiatorLog:
...
[note: no "allow CONFIG: */*" log messages]
...
11/03 15:11:12 PERMISSION GRANTED to unauthenticated user from host 127.0.0.1 for command 60003 (DC_CONFIG_RUNTIME), access level ALLOW: reason:
11/03 15:11:12 PERMISSION DENIED to unauthenticated user from host 127.0.0.1 for remote config A, access level CONFIG: reason: CONFIG authorization policy denies all access


config:
ENABLE_RUNTIME_CONFIG = TRUE
ALLOW_CONFIG = not.a.host, *
SETTABLE_ATTRS_CONFIG = *

test:
$ condor_config_val -neg -rset A=1
Successfully set configuration "A=1" on negotiator robin.local <127.0.0.1:51738>.

NegotaitorLog:
...
11/03 15:11:30 allow CONFIG:  */* */not.a.host
...
11/03 15:11:33 Adding to resolved authorization table: */127.0.0.1: CONFIG
11/03 15:11:33 PERMISSION GRANTED to unauthenticated user from host 127.0.0.1 for remote config A, access level CONFIG: reason: CONFIG authorization policy allows IP address 127.0.0.1; identifiers used for this remote host: 127.0.0.1,robin.local,robin,localhost.localdomain,localhost
remarks:
2009-Nov-03 17:36:09 by matt:
Known workarounds: 

ALLOW_CONFIG = *.*
ALLOW_CONFIG = *, somethingthatdoesntexist

2009-Nov-03 19:17:10 by danb:
This same behavior appears to be true in 7.2.4.

I think the responsible code in condor_ipverify.cpp is here: 

        // Treat a "*", "*/*" for USERALLOW_XXX as if it's just
        // undefined.

This code is not consistent with the fact that ALLOW_CONFIG defaults to denying all rather than allowing all.

This case does not happen to be one of the ones tested by condor_tests/lib_auth_config_tests, but it should be easy to add it.

2009-Nov-03 22:36:42 by matt:
Security documentation could use some cleaning. READ/WRITE/OWNER/CONFIG/etc are referred to as Permission Levels, Security Levels or Authroization Levels depending on where in the manual you happen to be reading.

2009-Nov-03 22:44:08 by danb:
Another case that I would consider to be broken: 

DENY_CONFIG = blah

That causes everyone except for blah to be allowed, even though the default for CONFIG is supposed to be to deny all unless they are explicitly added to the allow list.

2009-Nov-03 22:47:15 by matt:
SETTABLE_ATTRS is possibly an overly flexible set of parameters. First, it uses a deprecated SUBSYS_ instead of SUBSYS. notation. Second, it can work with any authorization level, e.g SETTABLE_ATTRS_OWNER checks for OWNER authorization while SETTABLE_ATTRS_CONFIG checks for CONFIG authorization. This flexibility allows for SETTABLE_ATTRS_OWNER=A,B,C and SETTABLE_ATTRS_CONFIG=X,Y,Z to be configured at the same time. However, what's the practical utility of being able to do this.

I propose a simplification, updating and making the configuration more clear.

First, the SUBSYS_ notation should be removed. SUBSYS. will work automatically.

Second, the _<Authorization Level> should be removed and all SETTABLE_ATTRS should always require the CONFIG level.

2009-Nov-03 22:50:52 by matt:
It seems SUBSYS_ has already been disabled. The manual needs to be updated.

2009-Nov-03 23:04:14 by danb:
In addition, things can be broken when using combinations of ALLOW and HOSTALLOW where one or the other is set to * but not both. Example: 

HOSTALLOW_WRITE = blah
ALLOW_WRITE = *

That is supposed to be equivalent to the concatenation of the two lists, but instead the * is ignored and only blah is allowed.

2009-Nov-03 23:06:53 by danb:
I have pushed a patch to V7_4-branch that addresses all of the problems mentioned so far in this ticket except for Matt's note that docs need to be improved and his complaint about SETTABLE_ATTRS stuff.

The original bug appears to go back to 2002 or earlier, according to some digging that Matt did.

2009-Nov-03 23:24:16 by matt:
I have filed 3 separate tickets for (#901 #902 #903) the three issues raised in these remarks. I'll mark this ticket as resolved.
